instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850A: What is 820-2850A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP1V05_S5: What is PP1V05_S5? PP1V05_S5 is a 1.05v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. On 2008-2009 15” and 17” Macbook boards, this often gets stuck at 0.3v due to a bad C7771 capacitor. .
definitions.P3V42_G3H: What is P3V42_G3H? P3V42_G3H is a typo of PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.SMC_TPAD_RST_L: What is SMC_TPAD_RST_L? SMC_TPAD_RST_L is a signal that comes from the trackpad that can reset the SMC when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. The trackpad having corrosion from liquid damage is a very common cause of no light on the magsafe charger & the system not turning on, when the trackpad or trackpad cable is corroded and holding this line down. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15" 2010 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light Liquid damage
threads.message:
Hi everyone, 
I have mentioned in title laptop for repair. 
Laptop starts working after cleaning there was a green light and fan spin and suddenly stoped giving any life. 
My measure:
<SIGNAL>5V5_S5</SIGNAL> present 
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present 
<SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> present 3.4V 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> - 0 V
<SIGNAL>PMSYSRST_L</SIGNAL> -0.00V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 0V 
I reflow SMC, I had a faulty <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR>. I replace it and also <TRANSISTOR>Q7225</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> but it didn't help. 
I think the problem is <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 0V but can't find out why it is not there, rail is not shorted I check main rails they are not shorted. 
Also I was checking for <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL>, <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> is not fitted on main board by manufacture but is present on schematic diagram. where I should measure this voltage than couldn't find this rail.
Thanks for any help.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15" 2010 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light Liquid damage
threads.message:
Post exact voltage for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Did you try another DCIN board?
Missing green light is a good point to start with.
Check <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> circuit.

"<CHIP>U7740</CHIP> is not fitted on main board"
Read what appears in schematic (alternative option), to understand why is not there.
Who cares about it, if you get <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL>...

Check all PCH's RTC signals too.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15" 2010 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light Liquid damage
threads.message:
Thanks for answers will check all mentioned signals, I have tested board with second DCIN board no changes.
Well I tried to find this voltage <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> and its not on 1st pad of this <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> place. Im not sure is not connected to this rail or its not present because I can't find place where it is generated or where else to measure it..

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15" 2010 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light Liquid damage
threads.message:
I check schematic regrading to this <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> voltage "Alternative is strong voltage dividers (200/100) to 3.3V S5"
Where this dividers can be find ? 
Thanks

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15" 2010 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light Liquid damage
threads.message:
Don't bother with it yet.
PCH is not involved in <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL>.

Try to reply us and we also try to help.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15" 2010 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light Liquid damage
threads.message:
Have now some measurement:
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> -12.58V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> -3.41V

Update: I measure also 
<SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST_L</SIGNAL> 3.40V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.40V

Looks like the <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> signal should be low but is not from some reason

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15" 2010 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light Liquid damage
threads.message: With those measurements, you should have a green light and it likely could be turning on... Tried new DC-in board? FOR SURE using 85 watt mag 1 charger?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15" 2010 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no green light Liquid damage
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> voltages.
Be sure to have continuity from its pin 5 to central pin of Magsafe connector.
Be aware, this board will NOT start with other charger than 85W; if battery is not connected.
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> low could mean incorrect charger.

"Looks like the <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> signal should be low"
Why do you expect that???
